awd_titl_txt: M(CP2): Minnesota Cybersecurity Pathway Curriculum Partnership for K-18
awd_abstract_narration:
The Metropolitan State University (Metro State) and Advance IT Minnesota have established a Cybersecurity Center with the mission of conducting research and educational activities intended to contribute to advances in formal and informal cybersecurity education. The NSF funded project, M(CP2): Minnesota Cybersecurity Pathway Curriculum Partnership for K-18, will be completed by the members and partners of the Cybersecurity Center. The outcome of the M(CP2) is an integrated curriculum pathway including course modules for K-12, A.S., B.S., M.S., and certificate programs. The modules and pathway will align with the forthcoming Association for Computing Machinery's Cybersecurity Curricula 2017: Curriculum Guidelines for Post-Secondary Degree Programs in Cybersecurity, and with Accreditation Board for Engineering and Technology (ABET) accreditation on cybersecurity. 

M(CP2) will employ an innovative public-private partnership approach to prototype the first industry-aligned integrated pathway curriculum for K-12 through M.S. By leveraging collaborative partners across industry, education, and the public sector, the proposed work will operationalize best practices in public-private cooperation for cybersecurity education developed by the National Institute of Standards and Technology - National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education (NICE) to expand comprehensive resources to develop and expand the pipeline of cybersecurity professionals. This work will provide educators and employers with a standardized pathway model, which will reduce inefficiencies among programs at various educational levels and enable schools and industry to better evaluate the training needs of current and future cybersecurity professionals. Furthermore, M(CP2) will serve as an example for existing programs to use as they align with the new guidelines; provide research-supported program plans and resources that new programs can replicate or customize; and, support integration of cybersecurity concepts into Computer Science for All projects by aligning project resources to the K-12 computer science pathways.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to advance cybersecurity education by creating an integrated, competency-based curriculum pathway spanning from K-12 to Master's level programs. Work focused on the following 4 domains:

 

1. Integrated Curriculum Pathway for Cybersecurity Education

The core objective of this project was to develop a cohesive and adaptable curriculum pathway that catered to students and professionals at various stages of their educational journey. A comprehensive document detailing the pathway informaiton was created and availble to public. Existing resources were coupled with curriculum developed under this project create this pathway, a significant step in a seamless connection between K-12, Associate's, Bachelor's, and Master's level programs, with all components competency based and articulated to workforce needs. The pathway serves as a comprehensive roadmap, ensuring that learners can enter at multiple points and progress efficiently through the levels. This integrated approach facilitates a continuous and progressive learning experience that aligns with the evolving demands of the cybersecurity profession. Moreover, it ensures that students and professionals are equipped with the knowledge and skills necessary to excel in the field.

2. Comprehensive Course Modules Supporting the Pathway

To support the integrated curriculum pathway, we have developed 240 course modules tailored to each educational level within the pathway, with a particular emphasis on curriculum at the post-secondary level. These modules cover a wide range of topics and skills essential to the field of cybersecurity. They are designed to be flexible, allowing educators to adapt them to their specific teaching contexts while ensuring alignment with the broader pathway objectives.

These course modules serve as building blocks for cybersecurity education. They provide educators with the tools needed to deliver high-quality instruction and empower students to acquire the competencies required for success in the profession. The modules have been meticulously crafted to reflect best instructional design principles, ensuring that learners receive a cutting-edge education and faculty members are supported in the implementation of the curriculum.

3. Effective Assessment of Learning Methods

One of the distinctive features of this project was its focus on assessing the effectiveness of both course-based and non-course-based learning methods across the curriculum pathway. We recognized the importance of understanding how various learning approaches contribute to the development of competencies in cybersecurity. Through rigorous assessment and data analysis, we have gained valuable insights into the impact of different learning methods. This research-driven approach has allowed us to refine our curriculum continuously, ensuring that it remains dynamic and responsive to the evolving needs of students and the cybersecurity industry.

4. Sustainability and Resource Sharing

The materials and resources developed as part of this project have not only benefited our immediate community but also contributed to the broader educational landscape in Minnesota. These resources have been institutionalized through the Minnesota State IT Center of Excellence, ensuring their long-term availability and accessibility to educators and learners across the state and nation-wide. This collaborative spirit aligns with our vision of expanding the reach and impact of our work beyond the confines of our institution. It reinforces the principle that excellence in cybersecurity education should be accessible to all.

Conclusion

Work initiated under this project remains ongoing, as the framework developed supports continued enhancement and expansion of cybersecurity education in Minnesota. This project provides an example of a curricular approach that is inclusive, adaptable, and ever-evolving to meet the demands of the digital age.

 


Last Modified: 08/29/2023
Modified by: Faisal Kaleem
